prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum in Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 16 pointings to measure the continuum in Band 7 of 16 extremely dust-rich sources in the COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SPECTRAL SETUP We require a single continuum spectral setup in Band 7 centered at 343.5 GHz. The spectral window suggested by the ALMA OT does not include atmospheric absorption lines. Band 7, in combination with available Herschel fluxes, allows an accurate dust mass estimate and at the same time samples a spectral region where the continuum is expected to be bright enough to be detected with short exposure times (4.7 min per source).
CALIBRATIONS We require standard calibrations.

IMAGING REQUIREMENTS We do not aim at spatially resolving our targets, hence the most compact configuration can be used. The source sizes have been estimated to be in the range 11-20 kpc, which correspond to a minimum and a maximum angular size of 1.6 and 2.4 arcsec, respectively, by considering each galaxy at the corresponding redshift. These numbers have been estimated from the mass-size relations of star-forming galaxies of Ichikawa et al. 2012 (R50 vs Mstar and R90 vs Mstar) and/or also by assuming the conversion of Graham et al. 2005 from the half-light radius (R50) to the radius containing 90% of the light (R90) for a profile with Sersic index of 1 (the minimum and maximum values have been chosen). We conservatively set the Largest Angular Structure to 4 arcsec to allow for a more extended distribution of the dust component compared to the stellar one. This size is two times smaller than the maximum recoverable scale given ALMA configuration (no ACA needed). We consider the entire predicted continuum flux for our targets as falling within a single beam of 1 arcsec. Infact, even if the sources are expected to be more extended, we are primarily interested in a continuum detection at the required sensitivity, which will be achieved by averaging different beams. As a by-product, we will also be able to produce a map of the dust spatial distribution for half of the sources (for which we expect a S/N>7 per beam) and to identify the overall trend in the dust distribution for most of them (i.e., either concentrated in the centre or in the external regions). However, this is not the scientific driver of the present proposal.
References: Graham et al. 2005, ApJ, 130, 1535; Ichikawa et al. 2012, MNRAS, 422, 1014.

SENSITIVITY REQUIREMENTS As described in the Scientific Justification, the expected continuum in Band 7 for the faintest target is 0.76 mJy. This value is estimated by assuming the most conservative template in the Elbaz et al. 2011 library (i.e., the starburst template). A sensitivity of 95 uJy will assure a 8 sigma detection of the thermal continuum for the faintest source and S/N>=11 for the other 15 out of 16 targets (out S/N~40 for the brightest one). If the less conservative main sequence template from the same library is adopted to estimate the continuum flux, the same sensitivity allows to detect the faintest source with S/N=12.
References: Elbaz et al. 2011, A&A, 533, A119.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent Herschel observations have revealed a large population of extremely dust-rich galaxies, with an amount of dust that is unexpected by even the most conservative theoretical calculations. Their large dust masses, if translated into gas by assuming a "standard" gas-to-dust ratio, lead to extremely high gas fractions, sometimes exceeding 90%. Moreover, if compared to their SFR, the large gas masses imply a very low star formation efficiency. This new population of dust-rich, gas-rich inefficient galaxies could represent a significant fraction of galaxies, which has been neglected so far, and which could be the nearby counterpart of Lyalpha absorbers at high-z. However, before making a sound and solid claim we have to first verify the reliability of their dust mass estimates. This can be easily achieved by ALMA with very limited exposure times.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Cambridge, University of
